{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3481445,"name":"Yuri","username":"Yuri10291","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/y/898d66/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-13T22:45:05.656Z","cooked":"

Hi guys, I’m part of a team from Brazil and my teammate asked me to ask what would be a better idea for a claw, whether it should have 3 or 2 points to grab the algae.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2025-01-14T11:58:29.839Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":47,"reads":397,"readers_count":396,"score":314.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":481505,"topic_slug":"a-question-idea-for-claw","display_username":"Yuri","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":71235,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/a-question-idea-for-claw/481505/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3481456,"name":"Josh","username":"AegisNova","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/aegisnova/{size}/265035_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-13T22:56:20.806Z","cooked":"

I’m guessing they mean 2/3 points of contact. But that really depends on if you want to follow a certain type of claw.
The three I’ve seen are

  • huge algae claws
  • using coral grabbers for claws
  • or just algae add-ons.

It also just depends on where the claw will be, because if it’s mounted to an elevator, then you could just use a coral grabber if you make it sturdy. But I couldn’t give you advice if you were planning on an arm, wrist, elbow, etc.

I see. I think you’ll find this team’s design very nice.

Team SCREAM 4522 and Team SCREAM Jr 4766 | Build Blog 2025 FRC Open Alliance
Alpha Bot V1 Week 1 has been a bit of a struggle due to multiple missed days due to snow and school cancellations. We have been busy working through CAD and have made a couple of prototypes. Here is our Alpha Bot V1 CAD to date. This will more than likely change as we get deeper into the prototyping of these systems. 4522 Alphabot CAD Drivebase Our drivebase is a standard 28" x 28" chassis with 3" x 1" tubes. Notably, our swerves are mounted the “normal” way as opposed to how we normally m…

Credit where credit’s due for their awesome idea.
However I don’t think you guys will need three prongs if you have a real solid grip on the coral and algae

One last question.
My mentor asked what do you think about throwing the algae onto the barge with the three-pronged claw?

This bot did a good job of showing how it’s possible, but it’s up to your team to decide if you want to do that.

vocês já deram uma olhada no design do pegador da equipe 4481? é uma ideia bem fácil de ser feita e bem leve! eles tem uma build thread bem completa.
Como é um mecanismo bem leve, ele pode ser acoplado com ou outro para manipular os Algas em uma torre. Isso possibilita a retirada das bolas do Reef de uma maneira mais fácil. O Ri3D da Penn State faz um mecanismo de uma bem eficiente!

Pra Gringo lê: Have you guys taken a look at the design of team 4481’s intake? It’s a very easy and light idea to do! they have a very complete build thread.
As it is a very light mechanism, it can be coupled with another to manipulate the Algae in a tower. This makes it easier to remove balls from the Reef. Penn State’s Ri3D makes a very efficient engine!
